Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research: Closing the loop between traffic/pollution sensing and vehicle route control using traffic lights and navigators

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today, most urban traffic control is rudimentary: in smaller cities, many traffic signals remain isolated, and while most larger cities have integrated systems of signals, they are still not dynamically timed in response to real-time vehicle information. Congestion fees, which are increasingly popular as a traffic management tool, are usually based on historical traffic data rather than varying dynamically to reflect instantaneous conditions. Recent advances in communication, navigation, and sensor technologies present far more opportunities to increase the intelligence and efficiency of metropolitan streets than are in place today.

This project focuses on designing a real-time networked sensing and actuation platform for future 'intelligent' metropolitan traffic management with the aim of simultaneously reducing congestion, pollution, and traveler delays. The pivotal element of the proposed Green City intelligent transport architecture is the ability to 'close the loop' between traffic/pollution sensing and traffic control; a system achieved through an incentivized collaboration between the central traffic management and the drivers. In this collaboration, the 'intelligent' traffic signals and the on-board navigators play key roles. Traffic signals sense traffic characteristics and vehicular emissions, collect data from vehicle sensors, and broadcast traffic advisories, routings, and restrictions to on-board navigators. The on-board navigators choose optimal routings taking into account drivers' preferences, local perceived traffic, and signal timing. All this is enabled by efficient vehicle to roadway infrastructure communications from 3G channels to DSRC radios.

Broader Impact: This project is highly interdisciplinary; it benefits from the collaboration and expertise of computer science, atmospheric science, and urban planning faculty and students. New education opportunities will result from the multidisciplinary nature of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today, traffic information is confined to road congestion and travel times. What if, in addition to travel times, pollution and air quality data is also provided on navigation maps? How would people use this information in travelling along "healthy" routes whether driving, biking or walking? This project addressed the issue of providing air quality data alongside navigation information so that people have the choice of shortest route or healthiest route. 

In order to provide a healthy route choice, fine-grained air quality data must be available. This project evaluated the use of cost-effective mobile sensors deployed on public transportation infrastructure. In addition, participatory sensing of pollution data was also evaluated. The most interesting  outcome of the work was the finding that the consumer of pollution data  for purposes of planning were people using non-vehicular modes of transportation even though the main source of pollution was vehicles!

To support our participatory sensing system for air quality data, given the distributed, peer-to-peer nature of vehicular networks, we opted for a distributed social network (DOSN). Our solution is based on Social Caches, which are members of the DOSN that act as local bridges between other members for efficient data dissemination. Essentially, by caching the social updates on social caches, we achieve scalable data dissemination  among social buddies through fewer network connections. 

As part of this project,  we designed a vehicle navigation system that allows the participating drivers to share routing decisions. Using this decision data, a cost-effective cooperative routing strategy was implemented. Instead of using computationally expensive optimizations, a heurestic was implemented that lets the users avoid 'popular' routes taken by other drivers. In this way, congestion is proactively alleviated and average travel time for all the drivers and air pollution are reduced. 

"What would have happened, had I taken the alternate route"? This is a question that many drivers often ponder hoping that their chosen route is the best. As part of our research, we studied the rationale for counterfactual thinking in route selection. We developed a method by which the actual travel times for alternate routes can be calculated by combining other drivers' travel times of segments that constitute the  alternate route.
